dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Italy just announced it's lifting its travel ban, one of Europe's earliest and most restrictive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Italy just announced it's lifting its travel ban, one of Europe's earliest and most restrictive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move lifts one of Europes earliest and most restrictive travel bans and paves the way for tourists to spend summer vacations in the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, so tourists can actually plan a summer vacation there now? That's huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, so tourists can actually plan a summer vacation there now? That's huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move lifts one of Europes earliest and most restrictive travel bans and paves the way for tourists to spend summer vacations in the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it paves the way for that, but uh, the announcement didn't specify if it applies to EU travelers only or everyone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it paves the way for that, but uh, the announcement didn't specify if it applies to E U travelers only or everyone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The announcement did not specify whether the measure only applies to travelers from the European Union, since the EU recommends external borders remain closed to foreign nationals until at least June 15.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, because the EU is recommending external borders stay closed to foreign nationals until at least June 15th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, because the E U is recommending external borders stay closed to foreign nationals until at least June fifteenth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The announcement did not specify whether the measure only applies to travelers from the European Union, since the EU recommends external borders remain closed to foreign nationals until at least June 15.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the U.S. State Department is still advising Americans to avoid all international travel, so it's a bit up in the air for non-Europeans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the U.S. State Department is still advising Americans to avoid all international travel, so it's a bit up in the air for non-Europeans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The U.S. State Department still advises citizens to avoid all international travel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, the Italian Embassy in Washington didn't immediately respond to questions about whether Americans can travel there on June 3rd.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, the Italian Embassy in Washington didn't immediately respond to questions about whether Americans can travel there on June third.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Italian Embassy in Washington D.C. did not immediately respond to questions from Forbes asking whether Americans or tourists from outside the EU will be allowed to travel to Italy on June 3.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like the priority is opening up internal borders first, like between European nations—Germany's doing something similar with France and Austria.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sounds like the priority is opening up internal borders first, like between European nations-Germany's doing something similar with France and Austria.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EU is urging countries to open up internal borders, allowing non-essential travel between European nations, before opening external ones. Germany, for example, opening its borders with France, Austria and Switzerland on June 15, creating a sort of travel bubble for the summer months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Creating a sort of travel bubble, yeah. And the Baltic countries are reopening to each other too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Creating a sort of travel bubble, yeah. And the Baltic countries are reopening to each other too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Baltic countries of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania too are reopening borders to one another.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It makes sense, given how hard Italy was hit early on. They've made progress though—only about 1,000 new COVID cases daily now, compared to 6,000 at the peak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It makes sense, given how hard Italy was hit early on. They've made progress though-only about ten hundred new COVID cases daily now, compared to six thousand at the peak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Italy experienced one of the earliest and most severe outbreaks in Europe, but the country has made progress in recent weeks: only 1,000 new COVID-19 cases are being reported daily, compared to 6,000 at the peak of the outbreak in March, according to the Washington Post.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And bars, restaurants, shops—they're reopening with social distancing rules. That's a big step.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And bars, restaurants, shops-they're reopening with social distancing rules. That's a big step.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bars, restaurants, shops, hairdressers and religious services will be able to open on Monday, while all other economic activity will be allowed to resume on June 3, provided businesses follow social distancing and disinfecting guidelines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For a country where tourism makes up 13% of GDP, you can see why they're eager to welcome people back safely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For a country where tourism makes up thirteen percent of G D P, you can see why they're eager to welcome people back safely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats how much the tourist industry makes up of Italys total gross domestic product.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Fingers crossed it all goes smoothly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Fingers crossed it all goes smoothly.

artist_script:
Sunshine and a spritz on a piazza, that's the Italian dream for so many this summer.
HostA: Italy just announced it's lifting its travel ban, one of Europe's earliest and most restrictive.
HostB: Oh wow, so tourists can actually plan a summer vacation there now? That's huge.
HostA: Yeah, it paves the way for that, but uh, the announcement didn't specify if it applies to EU travelers only or everyone.
HostB: Right, because the EU is recommending external borders stay closed to foreign nationals until at least June 15th.
HostA: Exactly. And the U.S. State Department is still advising Americans to avoid all international travel, so it's a bit up in the air for non-Europeans.
HostB: I mean, the Italian Embassy in Washington didn't immediately respond to questions about whether Americans can travel there on June 3rd.
HostA: It sounds like the priority is opening up internal borders first, like between European nations—Germany's doing something similar with France and Austria.
HostB: Creating a sort of travel bubble, yeah. And the Baltic countries are reopening to each other too.
HostA: It makes sense, given how hard Italy was hit early on. They've made progress though—only about 1,000 new COVID cases daily now, compared to 6,000 at the peak.
HostB: And bars, restaurants, shops—they're reopening with social distancing rules. That’s a big step.
HostA: For a country where tourism makes up 13% of GDP, you can see why they're eager to welcome people back safely.
HostB: Absolutely. Fingers crossed it all goes smoothly.
